greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Binomial(n+p, n) mod n where p=3.
comment: Let d(m)...d(2)d(1)d(0) be the base-n representation of n+p. The relation a(n)=d(1) holds, if n is a prime index. For this reason there are infinitely many terms which are equal to 1.
Appears to satisfy the recurrence: a(n) = -2*a(n-1) - a(n-2) + 2*a(n-3) + 4*a(n-4) + 2*a(n-5) - a(n-6) - 2*a(n-7) - a(n-8) for n > 14. - _Chai Wah Wu_, May 25 2016
link: G. C. Greubel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
formula: a(n)=1 if n is a prime > 3, since binomial(n+3,n)==(1+floor(3/n))(mod n), provided n is a prime.
if n mod 6 is in {1, 5}, then a(n) = 1.
if n mod 6 is in {2, 4}, then a(n) = n/2 + 1.
if n mod 6 == 3, then a(n) = n/3 + 1.
results.author: _Hieronymus Fischer_, Sep 30 2007
